splashscreen.title: Forest Loss
splashscreen.subtitle: Amazon Basin, Brazil
splashscreen.altText: Forest Loss in Amazon Basin, Brazil

slides.text: Rainforests worldwide are being destroyed at an alarming rate. The conversion of tropical rainforests to pastures and croplands is causing a dramatic effect on the landscape, biodiversity and environment.
This is of great concern as rainforests play an important role in our global climate. It is estimated that 20% of the Amazon biome has already been lost and the trend will worsen if gone unchecked.

slides.caption: 2020 above ground biomass in the Amazon Basin generated by ESA’s Climate Change Initiative. (ESA/CCI Biomass project)

Forest loss is defined as a change from a forest to non-forest state. The forest loss data, from the University of Maryland, has been overlaid onto the 2020 above ground biomass dataset, generated by ESA’s Climate Change Initiative.  (ESA/CCI Biomass project and Hansen/UMD/Google/USGS/NASA)
Deforestation and urban areas are clearly visible in shades of beige, light green and brown, while remaining untouched forest appears dark green. This image was captured on 8 July 1989. (USGS/ESA)
